title: DO NOT USE: Slaughtering and killing animals: licence exemptions

details.body:
To slaughter or kill an animal, you normally need one of the following:

  • a certificate of competence (CoC)
  • a Welfare of Animals at the Time of Killing (WATOK) licence
  • a Welfare of Animals (Slaughter or Killing) (WASK) licence

You don’t need any of them when slaughtering or killing:

  • for a non-commercial reason
  • for health (human or animal), animal welfare or environmental reasons
  • for reasons that aren’t covered by EU regulations (eg scientific experiments, hunting, fishing and shooting)
  • by shooting it in a field with a free-bullet firearm (a firearm that fires a single, high-speed shot)
  • while supervised by someone with a WATOK licence or CoC in the relevant operation
  • the animal in an emergency
  • farmed fox or mink
  • an animal not fit for human consumption

Killing poultry

You also don’t need a CoC or licence for:

  • decapitating or dislocating the necks of poultry on agricultural premises where they were reared
  • shackling poultry before stunning them
  • killing surplus chicks or embryos from hatcheries

Killing for your own consumption

You can kill an animal for your own consumption without getting a CoC or licence, unless you’re killing the animal in a slaughterhouse or a knacker’s yard.

Vet supervision

You don’t need a CoC or licence:

  • if you’re a vet killing an animal as part of your job
  • if you’re supervised by a vet

Exemptions for 3 years’ experience (transitional arrangements)

If you’ve got 3 years’ experience in a certain operation, with a certain species of animal and type of equipment, you can apply to the FSA for a CoC without doing an approved training course.

You must provide:

  • evidence of 3 years’ experience
  • a written declaration from a vet that you’re a fit and proper person to hold a certificate

Exemptions for certain procedures (transitional arrangements)

You won’t need a licence if you’re carrying out the procedures below and you were doing them before 1 January 2013:

  • caring for and handling animals before they’re restrained
  • shooting an animal in a field
  • shackling poultry before they’re stunned
